title: How many seats in the Congress of Deputies will the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) win in the next Spanish general election?
preds:
I have updated again my previous forecast, following the logic of: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/914330 But if you do not want to read it, the method is as follows: I have averaged the last few electoral polls, from 15 September till past week and find the variance. However I do not give each electoral poll the same weight: the most recent ones carry more weight. If they have been done in the last week, I give them a weight of 1, if they have been done more than one week ago but less than two weeks ago, I give them a weight of 1/2, etc. The polls are taken from [1], and the new values I obtain are: mu = 121.3. sigma = 3.5 (notice that they are not completely reproducible from [1] because they do not list the old polls done by a certain newspaper if there is a newer poll from said newspaper). To the previous sigma, I add a 2 seat intrinsic poll error to end up with sigma = 4.0, which lead to the probabilities I gave to each of the buckets. Time evolution: this week I have mu = 121.3, past week mu = 121.9,  two weeks ago 122.6 and three weeks ago 125.1. The downward trend is there, but it seems that it has stabilized. Unfortunately for the new equilibrium point the mean is close to the bucket division of 120 seats. This question has now become an effective Brier-score killer. Before I end, I would like to notice the much better election simulation by Kiko Llaneras in [2], in which they simulate province by province (the basic electoral district in Spain). His prediction is a 90% probability within the 90 to 139 seat range, with the mean located at 116. This would moderately change how to fill the buckets, with the biggest probability in the 108-120 range. [1] https://www.elmundo.es/espana/2019/09/25/5d81107021efa052498b464a.html
[2] https://elpais.com/politica/2019/11/03/actualidad/1572801969_634397.html#?ref=rss&format=simple&link=link
Updating as a result of this simulation: https://elpais.com/politica/2019/11/03/actualidad/1572801969_634397.html
Affirming. Polling has it at 121, but it's within the margin of error.
Updating as a resulting of recent polling: https://elpais.com/politica/2019/11/02/actualidad/1572722730_904341.html

I have updated again my previous forecast, following the logic of: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/914330 But if you do not want to read it, the method is as follows: I have averaged the last few electoral polls, from 15 September till past week and find the variance. However I do not give each electoral poll the same weight: the most recent ones carry more weight. If they have been done in the last week, I give them a weight of 1, if they have been done more than one week ago but less than two weeks ago, I give them a weight of 1/2, etc. The polls are taken from [1], and the new values I obtain are: mu = 121.9 sigma = 3.4 (notice that they are not completely reproducible from [1] because they do not list the old polls done by a certain newspaper if there is a newer poll from said newspaper). To the previous sigma, I add a 2 seat intrinsic poll error to end up with sigma = 4.0, which lead to the probabilities I gave to each of the buckets. Time evolution: this week I have mu = 121.9, compared to past week's 122.6, while two weeks ago it was 125.1. The downward trend is there, and unfortunately the mean is close to be on top of the bucket division of 120 seats. [1] https://www.elmundo.es/espana/2019/09/25/5d81107021efa052498b464a.html
They are likely to stay strong and gain more positions.

I've updated my forecast using more recent data [1] and it looks like voter intention for PSOE is moving incrementally downwards to 27.5-28%. I've made slight adjustments to my forecast as a result of this, reducing the probability of >132-144 slightly and splitting this between 108-120 and 120-<132. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_November_2019_Spanish_general_election
Tightening my forecast based on stable polling.

I have updated again my previous forecast, following the logic of: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/914330 But if you do not want to read it, the method is as follows: I have averaged the last few electoral polls, from 15 September till past week and find the variance. However I do not give each electoral poll the same weight: the most recent ones carry more weight. If they have been done in the last week, I give them a weight of 1, if they have been done more than one week ago but less than two weeks ago, I give them a weight of 1/2, etc. The polls are taken from [1], and the new values I obtain are:  mu = 122.6, sigma = 3.7  (notice that they are not completely reproducible from [1] because they do not list the old polls done by a certain newspaper if there is a newer poll from said newspaper). To the previous sigma, I add a 2 seat intrinsic poll error to end up with sigma = 4.2, which lead to the probabilities I gave to each of the buckets. Now, with a larger set of data: there is indication of a time evolution towards a smaller number of seats. Past week my poll average yielded  mu = 125.6, sigma = 3.2 (before adding the correction to sigma), while two weeks ago I had mu = 125.1, sigma = 3.7. The time evolution suggests that the 108-120 bucket is underrepresented and the probability is higher than the 30% I have given to it. However taking this into account is not trivial, as it will require to correctly assess the time evolution and how errors compound in it. [1] https://www.elmundo.es/espana/2019/09/25/5d81107021efa052498b464a.html
Catalan weighs down socialist. So i think they end up where they are 123 seats.
I suspect voters will punish PSOE for both not doing more to form government after winning the last election and the handling of the Catalan situation.

The trend over time is towards a lower % of the popular vote for PSOE. Giving a 50% weighting to the October polls, a 30% weighting to September and 20% to August it looks like PSOE would win 124 seats. This suggests that the most likely outcome is within the same bracket as the previous result. However, the October polls alone indicate that PSOE will win only 119 seats. 
Because of the above, I’ve dropped the likelihood of the middle bracket and the upper brackets in favour of lower outcomes.

Just found this model by El Pais based that takes the average of the most recent polling and tries to account for Spain's use of the D'Hondt method: https://elpais.com/politica/2019/10/15/actualidad/1571151830_085106.html My own model seems to be significantly off compared to this, meaning my approximation of the D'Hondt method was pretty far off.

I have updated my previous forecast, which can be found here (for the rationale): https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/914330 But if you do not want to read it, the method is as follows: I have averaged the last few electoral polls, from 15 September till past week and find the variance. However I do not give each electoral poll the same weight: the most recent ones carry more weight. If they have been done in the last week, I give them a weight of 1, if they have been done more than one week ago but less than two weeks ago, I give them a weight of 1/2, etc. The polls are taken from [1], and the new values I obtain are: mu = 125.6, sigma = 3.2 (notice that they are not completely reproducible from [1] because they do not list the old polls done by a certain newspaper if there is a newer poll from said newspaper). To the previous sigma, I add a 2 seat intrinsic poll error to end up with sigma = 3.8, which lead to the probabilities I gave to each of the buckets. Now, with a larger set of data: I do not find statistically strong evidence of time evolution in the polls (for the seats of the socialist party). For the moment I will not include it. [1] https://www.elmundo.es/espana/2019/09/25/5d81107021efa052498b464a.html

I've made a model to try to estimate the actual functioning of Spain's system of proportional representation. Spain uses the D'Hondt method [1], which slightly favors larger parties [2]. Spain's electoral system also has some particularities that are difficult to incorporate into a model: "A party must obtain a minimum of 3 percent of the vote in order to qualify for parliamentary representation. Each province is to have a minimum of two seats in the Congress of Deputies, plus one additional seat for every 144,500 inhabitants or fraction over 70,000 inhabitants...This system tends to overrepresent the more traditional, rural, and thinly populated parts of Spain and to favor the larger parties, which also benefit from the system of postelectoral subsidies." [3]  I tried to account for the particularities of Spain's electoral system by finding the estimated error in #seats from: the actual #seats allotted to each party in the past three elections vs. the hypothetical #seats allotted to each party in the past three elections if all of Spain were a single, completely unified proportional system. I combined this output with the average of polling (from Politico's poll of polls) to get a final result of ~121 seats [4]. I am not extremely confident in this model as it is very crude in its approximation of Spain's electoral system, so I assigned a standard deviation of 5.5 to this value. I then used a normal distribution calculator [5] to find the probabilities I should assign to each bin. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Spain
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party-list_proportional_representation
[3] http://countrystudies.us/spain/74.htm
[4] My model (please feel free to make comments!): https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1KpEgkA8fPdSZH-n7Z5Lfn9TuTsrFll04VudRuMvaqho/edit?usp=sharing
[5] https://stattrek.com/online-calculator/normal.aspx

I have tried to refine the methodology with respect to my previous forecast and updated my predictions. First, let me explain my method: I have averaged the last few electoral polls, from 15 September till past week and find the variance. However I do not give each electoral poll the same weight: the most recent ones carry more weight. If they have been done in the last week, I give them a weight of 1, if they have been done more than one week ago but less than two weeks ago, I give them a weight of 1/2, etc. The results from the electoral polls are taken from [1] (in Spanish), which halfway down contains a typical pie chart for the congress seats and where one can choose a concrete poll (it indicates the dates), after which the number of seats predicted in that particular poll will appear. It should be easy to use for non-spanish speakers (it does not require much Spanish to find the pie-distribution figure of the congress). The weighted outcome with the weighting procedure I have used is: mu = 125.1, sigma = 3.7 Then for the sigma, I must add the intrinsic sigma of each poll, which probably averages on two seats (as can be appreciated in the few polls that give you a range of seats instead of a single number). Assuming no correlation, this translates into a total sigma = 4.2 Then I simply find the probability in each of the brackets (but one needs to take into account that, for instance, "120 included" would translate into 119.5 or more, as we are approximating with a continuous probability distribution). This is however the outside view. For the inside (or should I say, mixed inside-outside) view I would recommend a recent article by Kiko Llaneras [2], where he indicates that there is a downward tendency in the voting intentions to the socialist party. This could be taken into account by trying to extrapolate the means of the polls done in different moments of time, but I have not done such an exercise yet. Edit 1: by taking the four polls made last week and the six polls made three weeks ago, the mean has gone down by 1.25 seats. This would naively translate into five seats in the four weeks resting to the elections. However, this has to be compounded with the inherent error of the polls and the previous error after averaging, meaning that it's not clear how to translate this into a statistically sound time evolution of the voting intention. [1] https://www.elmundo.es/espana/2019/09/25/5d81107021efa052498b464a.html
[2] https://elpais.com/politica/2019/10/07/actualidad/1570458030_601164.html

List of polls here [1] showing a negative trend last couple of weeks to the 121-125 range. Therefore concentrating in the 108-120 and 120-132 ranges. Another factor, the "impossible promises" as indicator of trend of inside info (the more crazy the promises, the worse the inside info). We had at least two of them in last days, about pensions increases in December and relaxing conditions for unemployment subsidies (due to commercial war). 37/63  [1] https://electocracia.com

I took a weighted average of the top 9 most accurate polling companies from the last election (the tenth most accurate hasn't made a forecast yet). This suggests a slightly better result for the PSOE in terms of the popular vote (29.7% vs 28.7%). Because of the regional D'Hondt system, we can't exactly translate the popular vote to seats but I don't have anything else to go on so I've assumed that the result will be a 3.5% increase in the number of seats won. That puts the PSOE on around 127 seats in the upcoming election.
As this puts the PSOE on the upper half of the probability brackets I've hedged my bets slightly more towards 132-144 than 108-120.
The more extreme brackets seem to be a slim possibility based on my reading of the popular press. The last election was only a few months ago so a collapse of the vote seems unlikely especially as the main right of centre rivals to the PSOE have reportedly lost votes to smaller parties on the right. As the electoral system in Spain benefits larger parties, this should work in favour of the PSOE. I've put 5% in the >144 bracket to cover the chance that voters are tired of a hung parliament that they choose to back the party most likely to win.

Right now the party is up a few points from their polling average in the last election where they won 123 seats. Based on that I think they earn a few more seats than that. However, their numbers have trended downward recently so they could end up with future. I will have to see how the trend lines evolve over the next few weeks.
PSOE has 123 seats now.  They are not going to get fewer.  There is an outside chance they pickup 20 or more seats, it is not zero. Most likely they land in the 123 to 140 range.

Ahora,
Gobierno.
Ahora, 
España. Sanchez has made a conciliatory, moderate, campaign launch with a meaning(less/ful) patriotic campaign message. +5 to 120-132

The poll from CIS with projections [1] and direct vote (comparable, not adjusted) series [2]. It does not include Más País, a new left-eft party competing with Unidas Podemos. It is interesting that expect higher % for PSOE (socialists) and Unidas Podemos (extreme left) and slightly higher for PP (centre right-right) while lower for Ciudadanos (centre right) and Vox (extreme right). The poll might not be representative, but when compared to Feb 2019, two months earlier than the previous
April 28th general elections, PSOE is 3 pp higher and PP 2 pp lower. April 28th general elections' results here [3], PSOE ended with 28% - 123 seats. PSOE's leader, Pedro Sanchez forced this snap elections under the assumption it will do better this second chance. Más País might damage both PSOE and Unidas Podemos, but we cannot think it was by chance, unknown to the Government, that it came right at this time, and will impact Unidas Podemos much more than PSOE. I expect then better results than in April 28th. On the other side, there could be a reaction from voters moving them away from the voting schools or punishing PSOE for not being able to from a government or coalition. Slightly lower in seats. Bottom line: 30% - 60% - 10% [1] https://elpais.com/politica/2019/09/26/actualidad/1569481947_976543.html
[2] http://www.cis.es/cis/export/sites/default/-Archivos/Indicadores/documentos_html/sB606050010.html
[3] https://www.abc.es/elecciones/elecciones-generales/resultados/

I simply made an average of the last eight polls published. Yesterday there was the CIS poll, which a sample size around 6000 (considerably bigger than the usual 1000-1500 sample polls), giving a larger than expected percentage of the vote to the PSOE. However it did not indicate the expected seats, which are very dependent on vote distribution. It would be wise to update once there is the seat estimation from the CIS.

Elections in Spain take place under the D'Honte method, a form of proportional representation. The highest PSOE have been in the polls this year has been 33% (https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/spain/). In 2016, the PP won 137 seats with 32% of the vote. Polls have been broadly steady for them with a slight decline over the past few months

"The Socialists would gain 11 seats to win 134, a GAD3 poll carried out for Vanguardia newspaper showed, still not enough for a majority of 176. Podemos would lose 5 seats, the poll showed."[1] Most recent GAD3 and other polls project ~120. They won 123 in the April election. In 2016, it was 85. It seems unlikely that much will change. There's some fragmentation on the left that might help PSOE, so putting the bulk on the middle option that they pick up a few seats. [1] https://news.yahoo.com/spains-socialist-party-maintain-lead-075640570.html
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_next_Spanish_general_election
